title: IHG weathers slowing revenues in China
text:
InterContinental weathers slowing revenue growth in China By Joel Lewin ©Dreamstime 
InterContinental Hotels Group endured a slowing of revenue growth in the third quarter, with a decline in China cushioned by a strong performance in Europe and solid figures from the US. 
The company, the world’s largest hotel operator by number of rooms, reported revenue per available room — the industry’s preferred measure of sales — rose 4.8 per cent across the group in the third quarter, compared with 5.8 per cent in the first half of the year and 5.1 per cent in the year to date. However, the data still outperformed analysts’ forecasts of an increase of just 3.9 per cent. More Fantasy sports groups fight for survival 
Richard Solomons, IHG chief executive, said: “Looking ahead to the remainder of this year, we are encouraged by current trading trends and remain confident in the outlook.” 
Regional figures for revenue per available room in the quarter were up 4.3 per cent — 7.1 per cent in Asia, the Middle East and Africa and 7.8 per cent in Europe, fuelled by “solid trading in Germany, and double digit growth across southern Europe and Russia . . . reflecting signs of recovery in these markets” — but down 0.7 per cent in Greater China, as occupancy growth was offset by a decline in room rates, the company reported. 
Analysts had been expecting growth of 0.8 per cent in China. However, the company noted that revenue per available room in mainland China was up 2.1 per cent. 
In September, IHG suffered a share price wobble as fears that global geopolitical and macroeconomic issues would hurt demand appeared to materialise when its US peer Host Hotels & Resorts trimmed its earnings guidance amid weak demand in August. A number of US hotel real estate investment trusts, including La Quinta and Pebblebrook, also cut guidance last month, sparking concerns that expansion by large hotel operators has not been matched by rising demand. 
IHG continued its pursuit of an “asset-light strategy” of reducing its property portfolio while retaining management contracts to operate the hotels. In July, the group sold its flagship Hong Kong hotel for $938m — well over the $298m valuation for the building. The completion of the sale of InterContinental Hong Kong “marks the successful conclusion of our major owned asset disposal programme”, Mr Solomons said. 
Activist investors including Nelson Peltz and more recently US hedge fund Marcato have been scrutinising the group’s management in recent years. Last year, the company returned more than $1bn to shareholders, including a $763m special dividend in May. 
In July, the FT reported that IHG had held early stage talks with Starwood Hotels & Resorts over a union to create the world’s largest hotel group, after Starwood effectively put itself up for sale in April. IHG responded that it was not at that time in talks with Starwood with a view to a combination of the businesses. There is also chatter that the Holiday Inn owner is reportedly close to buying luxury hotel chain Fairmont. 
IHG shares are up 6.5 per cent in the last 12 months, ahead of the FTSE 100 which has climbed just 1.5 per cent in the same period.
